creator: crozierm@conducivetech.com
text:
I am using mod_jk2 to load balance sticky sessions between several
out-of-process tomcat instances.  When I disable a worker gracefully, then
attempt to re-enable it via workers2.properties, the worker is never used since
the lb_value is set to zero.  The only way to get lb_value back to normal for
that worker is to restart apache, which disrupts the sticky session load balancing.

creator: crozierm@conducivetech.com
text:
Apologies, I  confused the issue.  The problem is when apache is starting with a 
particular worker/channel disabled.   Because the lb_value is initially set to zero, that 
particular worker cannot be enabled without restarting apache. 
 
I had thought I'd seen lb_value at zero without an apache restart, but I cannot 
reproduce it now.

Marking as invalid based on user's comments. (Just trying to keep bugzilla
clean, please reopen if you think otherwise.)
creator: funkman@joedog.org
crozierm@conducivetech.com
text:
Nope, I still think its a bug, it just isn't the same bug that I originally described ;-) 
 
If you start apache with a worker disabled, you can never enable that worker without 
restarting apache.  So if you want to start apache with only 1 ajp worker enabled, you 
can never add another worker without disrupting existing "sticky" sessions. 
 
As a work around, I've altered my apache start script to modify workers2.properties, 
start apache, disable the workers that were previously disabled, and HTTP GET 
/jkstatus/ to pick up the changes.  This is a significantly more involved process than it 
could be.

creator: funkman@joedog.org
text:
As of November 15, 2004, JK2 is no longer supported. All bugs related to JK2 
will be marked as WONTFIX. In its place, some of its features have been 
backported to jk1. Most of those features will be seen in 1.2.7, which is 
slated for release on November 30th, 2004.

Another alternative is the ajp addition to mod_proxy which will be part of 
apache 2.
